The right of states to govern themselves, to make decisions regarding their own institutions and economic systems, was a deeply held principle among the Southern states.

When the federal government, particularly through the election of Abraham Lincoln in 1860, began to push policies that many in the South viewed as an unconstitutional threat to their way of life, they saw no other recourse but to assert their right to secede. The Southern states believed they had the same right to leave the Union that the original colonies had to break away from Britain.

The issue of slavery, while significant, was not the central cause but rather a symptom of a deeper conflict over the balance of power between state and federal authority. Many in the South did not view secession as primarily about slavery but as a defense of their constitutional rights to self-governance and economic independence.

The Civil War, therefore, was a tragic but necessary confrontation over the fundamental question of whether the states or the federal government would hold ultimate authority in the American republic.
